column1: Pain, hearing loss, dizziness, ringing in the ear, and ruptured eardrums can be caused by: - Inserting cotton swabs, toothpicks, pins, pens, or other objects into the ear - Sudden changes in pressure, as from an explosion, blow to the head, flying, scuba diving, falling while water skiing, or being slapped on the head or ear - Loud sounds, such as a gun firing

- Bleeding from the ear - Bruising or redness - Clear liquid coming out of the ear (brain fluid) - Dizziness - Earache - Loss of hearing - Nausea and vomiting - Noises in the ear - Sensations of an object in the ear - Swelling - Visible object in the ear
RUPTURED EARDRUM - The person will have severe pain.
CUTS ON THE OUTER EAR - Apply direct pressure until the bleeding stops.
- Apply cold compresses over the dressing to reduce pain and swelling.
- Have the person lie down on the side with the affected ear down so that it can drain.
- DO NOT attempt to remove the object by probing with a cotton swab, a pin, or any other tool.
See a doctor if you have: - Pain in the ear - Ringing sounds - Dizziness (vertigo) - Hearing loss - Drainage or blood from the ear - Recent blow to your ear or head
- After an ear injury, avoid nose blowing and getting water in the injured ear.
If you tend to feel pain and pressure in your ears when flying: - Drink a lot of fluid before and during the flight.
